[[Image:Sword in the Stone.jpg|thumb|Cover of White's ''The Sword in the Stone'']]
'''Terence Hanbury White''' (29 May 1906 â€“ 17 January 1964) was an English author best known for his sequence of Arthurian novels, ''[[Wikipedia:The Once and Future King|The Once and Future King]]''.

[[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote that he had read White's novel ''[[Wikipedia:The Sword in the Stone|The Sword in the Stone]]'' (published in [[1938]]).<ref group="note">Tolkien's statement is found in an unpublished manuscript, kept with restricted access at the [[Bodleian Library]].</ref><ref>{{CG|RG}}, "Reading", p. 818</ref><ref name=LP>[http://www.lotrplaza.com/forum/forum_posts.asp?TID=235623 Tolkien and T. H. White] at [http://www.lotrplaza.com/ Lotrplaza.com] (accessed 4 May 2011)</ref>

[[Richard C. West]] has published an article, "Contemporary Medieval Authors" (''[[Orcrist]]'' 3/''Tolkien Journal'' whole no. 11; January 1970), in which Tolkien, White and [[C.S. Lewis]] are compared. [[Tom Shippey]] mentions White, Tolkien, [[Wikipedia:William Golding|Golding]], [[Wikipedia:George Orwell|Orwell]], and others, in a "''discussion of postwar English writers''", in ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Author of the Century]]''.<ref name=LP/>
